knowledge_graph.title: Energy transition
knowledge_graph.description: An energy transition is a major structural change to energy supply and consumption in an energy system. Currently, a transition to sustainable energy is underway to limit climate change. Most of the sustainable energy is renewable energy. Therefore, another term for energy transition is renewable energy transition.

related_questions.question: What is energy transition in United States?
related_questions.snippet: Clean electricity transition continued as demand rose The United States' shift towards clean electricity continued in 2024, as wind and solar together rose to 17% of total electricity generation, surpassing coal, which dropped to an all-time low of 15%.

related_questions.question: What is an example of a transition energy?
related_questions.snippet: Historically, energy transitions are fueled by innovation and necessity. For example, industrialization drove the transition from burning wood to burning coal, while the internal combustion engine and production of gas-powered vehicles precipitated the world's reliance on oil.
related_questions.title: What Is an Energy Transition? - IBM

text_blocks.snippet: The energy transition refers to the global shift from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources like solar, wind, and hydroelectric power, aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change. It's a fundamental transformation in how we produce, distribute, and consume energy. This transition involves not only generating electricity from renewables but also decarbonizing other sectors like transportation and heating.
snippet_highlighted_words: the global shift from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources like solar, wind, and hydroelectric power, aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change

text_blocks.snippet: Key aspects of the energy transition:

list.title: Shift away from fossil fuels:
list.snippet: The core of the transition involves phasing out coal, oil, and natural gas, which are major contributors to greenhouse gas emissions.

list.title: Embracing renewable energy:
list.snippet: This includes expanding the use of solar, wind, geothermal, hydroelectric, and other sustainable energy sources.

list.title: Decarbonizing other sectors:
list.snippet: The transition extends beyond electricity generation, encompassing the electrification of transportation, heating, and other sectors to reduce their reliance on fossil fuels.

list.title: Technological advancements:
list.snippet: Innovation in energy storage, smart grids, and energy efficiency technologies are crucial for enabling a smooth and effective transition.

list.title: Policy and regulatory support:
list.snippet: Government policies, international agreements, and financial incentives play a vital role in accelerating the transition.

list.title: Just transition:
list.snippet: This concept emphasizes that the transition should be equitable, ensuring that vulnerable communities and workers are not disproportionately affected and benefit from the shift to a green economy.

text_blocks.snippet: Why is the energy transition important?

list.title: Combating climate change:
list.snippet: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions is essential to mitigate the impacts of global warming, such as rising temperatures, extreme weather events, and sea-level rise.

list.title: Improving energy security:
list.snippet: Diversifying energy sources and reducing reliance on volatile global markets can enhance energy independence and resilience.

list.title: Creating new economic opportunities:
list.snippet: The transition to a green economy can foster innovation, create jobs in renewable energy and related industries, and promote sustainable development.

list.title: Protecting public health:
list.snippet: Reducing air and water pollution from fossil fuel extraction and combustion can improve public health outcomes.
